ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze extremely dense philosophical text.
Philosophical writing in the key of german idealism; interpreting Hegel's style. The dialectical method.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It can be later in the day, or it can have more philosophy students. The divinity school students who took the class were very lost, and it was often times awkward because not that many people spoke in the seminar.

Strengths: seminar style discussion, keeps the class open to ideas. Weaknesses: I thought the class could be a bit more directed; and if smaller, the seminar discussion would have been more effective.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The class is a bit of a grind because it's a two-hour seminar at 9:25am. It's also on Hegel and on dense text, so it's not the most engaging class unless you are very interested in the material. However, I was really engaged in the material so I really liked it. But be warned, this is not your average philosophy class. If you are not excited about Hegel, don't take it because it can be painful and confusing. It requires weekly reading responses and two papers, as well as a huge amount of reading each week.
